{{For|other people named Dusty Rhodes|Dusty Rhodes (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox professional wrestler |name = Dusty Rhodes |birthname = Virgil Riley Runnels Jr. |names = Dusty Rhodes{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/d/dusty-rhodes.html|title=Dusty Rhodes' profile|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=June 7, 2011}}
Dusty Runnels
The Midnight Rider
Mr.Ichiban |image = Dusty Rhodes cropped and retouched.jpg |caption = Rhodes circa 2008 |spouse = {{marriage|Sandra Runnels|1965|1975|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Michelle Runnels|1978|2015|reason=his death}} |family = [[Brandi Rhodes]] (daughter-in-law)
[[Fred Ottman]] (brother-in-law)
[[Jerry Sags]] (brother-in-law) |children = 4, including [[Goldust|Dustin Runnels]], [[Cody Rhodes|Cody Runnels]] |height = 6 ft 1 in |weight = 289 lb |birth_date = {{Birth date|1945|10|11}} |birth_place = [[Austin, Texas]], United States |death_date = {{death date and age|2015|06|11|1945|10|11}} |death_place = [[Orlando, Florida]], United States |death_cause= [[Kidney failure]] |billed = Austin, Texas
Diablo Canyon, Colorado |trainer = [[Joe Blanchard]]{{cite book|title=National Wrestling Alliance: The Untold Story of the Monopoly That Strangled Pro Wrestling|last=Hornbaker|first=Tim|pages=329–332|publisher=[[ECW Press]]|year=2007|isbn=978-1-55022-741-3}}{{cite book|title=Dusty: Reflections of an American Dream|last1=Rhodes|first1=Dusty|last2=Brody|first2=Howard|page=2|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC|year=2005|isbn=978-1-58261-907-1}} |debut = 1967{{cite web|url=http://wrestlingclassics.com/.ubb/ultimatebb.php?ubb=get_topic;f=10;t=003726#000006|title=When did Dusty Rhodes make his debut in pro wrestling?|work=wrestlingclassics.com}} |retired = 2007 }} '''Virgil Riley Runnels Jr.''' (October 11, 1945 – June 11, 2015), better known as '''"The American Dream" Dusty Rhodes''', was an American [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]], booker, and trainer who most notably worked for the [[National Wrestling Alliance]], [[Jim Crockett Promotions]], and the World Wrestling Federation, later known as the [[WWE]]. Following his retirement from wrestling, he made occasional on-air appearances on WWE television and pay-per-views and worked as a backstage [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Book|booker]] and [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Agent|producer]] in WWE's [[NXT (WWE brand)|NXT]] developmental territory. Billed as "the son of a plumber", Rhodes did not have a typical wrestler's physique; his character was that of the "[[Working class|Common Man]]", known for the personality exhibited in his interviews. WWE chairman [[Vince McMahon]] remarked that no wrestler "personified the essence of charisma quite like Dusty Rhodes".{{Cite episode|series=Celebrating the Dream|network=[[WWE Network]]|station=[[WWE]]|date=June 15, 2015|minutes=0}} Rhodes was a three-time [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship|NWA World Heavyweight Champion]], and during his time in Jim Crockett Promotions, later known as [[World Championship Wrestling|WCW]], he was a [[WWE United States Championship|United States Heavyweight Champion]], and multi-time [[WCW Television Championship|World Television]], [[WCW World Tag Team Championship|World Tag Team]] and [[WCW World Six-Man Tag Team Championship|World Six-Man Tag Team Champion]]. He also won many regional championships, and is one of six men inducted into each of the [[WWE Hall of Fame|WWE]], [[WCW Hall of Fame|WCW]], [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame|Professional Wrestling]], and ''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame|Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]'' Halls of Fame. His sons, [[Goldust|Dustin]] and [[Cody Rhodes|Cody]], both pursued careers in professional wrestling and performed for WWE. == Professional wrestling career == === Early career (1967–1974) === After graduating from [[Arlington Heights High School]] in [[Fort Worth]], Rhodes played [[baseball]] and [[American football|football]] for [[West Texas A&M Buffaloes football|West Texas State]] (now known as [[West Texas A&M University]]). Turning professional, Rhodes tried out for the [[American Football League]]'s [[Boston Patriots]] but was cut. He then played for the Hartford Charter Oaks in the [[Continental Football League]] until the team folded.{{cite web|url=http://podcastone.com/Steve-Austin-Show|title=The Steve Austin Show - Unleashed! EP66 - Dusty Rhodes - November 21st, 2013|work=podcastone.com}} In 1967, Rhodes saw an advertisement in the newspaper for Tony Santos’ [[professional wrestling]] promotion Big Time Wrestling, based in [[Boston]]. Rhodes drove to Boston, and despite not having any wrestling experience, bluffed his way into working for the company by using his real life friendships with [[Bobby Duncum Sr.|Bobby Duncum]] and the Funk brothers. Billed as Dusty Runnels, one of his first matches was for the BTW World Heavyweight title against champion Frank Scarpa in the [[Boston Arena]]. Having little money, Rhodes slept in his car and spent [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] with [[Rufus R. Jones]] in a [[Boston]] [[soup kitchen]]. Rhodes moved on to [[Fritz Von Erich]]'s Texas territory [[World Class Championship Wrestling]] in 1968, at that time also called Big Time Wrestling. It was in Texas where Rhodes first adopted the ring name "Dusty Rhodes".{{cite web |url=http://www.midatlanticgateway.com/p/career-results-dusty-rhodes_26.html|title=Career Results – Dusty Rhodes |work=midatlanticgateway.com}} Upon meeting Rhodes, [[Gary Hart (wrestler)|Gary Hart]] suggested that he change his [[ring name]] to "Lonesome Rhodes", a character [[Andy Griffith]] portrayed in the film ''[[A Face in the Crowd (film)|A Face in the Crowd]]''. Rhodes reportedly replied: "Well...I don’t plan on being 'Lonesome'. I think I’ll stick with Dusty."{{Cite book|title=My Life In Wrestling: With A Little Help From My Friends|last=Hart|first=Gary|publisher=GEAN Publishing|year=2009|isbn=0692000461|location=United States of America|pages=33–35}} Hart took an immediate liking to Rhodes and convinced Von Erich of the young wrestler's potential. Rhodes became a rule-breaking [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heel]] with Hart as his [[Manager (professional wrestling)|manager]], teaming with [[Don Jardine]], better known as The Spoiler. Later in 1968, Rhodes left Texas and entered the [[Heart of America Sports Attractions|Kansas City]] territory, tagging with fellow Texan [[Dick Murdoch]] to form the [[tag team]] '''The Texas Outlaws'''. The team traveled both nationally and internationally, appearing in Big Time Wrestling (Texas), NWA Western States Sports (Texas), NWA Detroit, [[National Wrestling Federation]] (NWF), [[Championship Wrestling from Florida]], [[World Championship Wrestling (Australia)]], [[Universal Wrestling Federation (Bill Watts)|Tri-State Wrestling]], the [[American Wrestling Association]] (AWA), and [[International Wrestling Enterprise]] (Japan).{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/dustyrhodes|title=Dusty Rhodes' bio|publisher=[[WWE]]|accessdate=June 9, 2011}}{{cite book|title=Sex, Lies, and Headlocks|author1=Assael, Shaun |author2=Mike Mooneyham|publisher=Crown Publishers|year=2002|isbn=0609606905|pages=73–78}} === National Wrestling Alliance territories (1974–1984) === [[File:Dusty Rhodes Bionic Elbow 2.jpg|thumb|Rhodes performing his finishing maneuver, the ''bionic elbow'', in 1979]] {{quote box|width=30em|align=left|quote=Rising to prominence in the era of steroids and bleached-blond hair, Rhodes was the rare top-end superstar who didn't possess the hulking, bodybuilder physique. In fact, Dusty's was quite the opposite, with his rotund belly and conspicuous red blotch on his right side. Rhodes' figure was a huge key to his success at the box office as the ultimate sympathetic babyface. Chubby and loveable, Rhodes was never afraid to endure an incredible scripted beating in order to draw the most heat for his heel opponents.|source=—Brian Campbell, ESPN}} Rhodes did not have a typical wrestlers' physique, but he was well known for his personality, charisma and interviews.{{Cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2015/06/11/22447761.html|title=Dusty Rhodes=Charisma|publisher=Slam! Sports|date=June 11, 2015|accessdate=June 12, 2015|author=Oliver, Greg}} In 1974, Rhodes's character became a [[Face (professional wrestling)|hero]] after tag team partner [[Pak Song]] and manager [[Gary Hart (wrestler)|Gary Hart]] turned on him during a match in Florida against [[Eddie Graham|Eddie]] and [[Mike Graham (wrestler)|Mike Graham]]. This led him to break out as a solo wrestler, primarily in [[Florida]], referring to himself as the "American Dream", a [[working class]] hero, and aligning himself with Eddie Graham.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2015/06/11/22447706.html|title=JJ Dillon's speech for Dusty Rhodes' induction into the Pro Wrestling Hall of Fame|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=June 15, 2015|date=April 11, 2015}} In 1977, Rhodes wrestled for [[Vince McMahon, Sr.]]'s [[WWE|World Wide Wrestling Federation]] (WWWF) on and off for lengthy periods of time until 1981. During that time, Rhodes main-evented twice in Madison Square Garden, both times challenging for the [[WWE World Heavyweight Championship|WWWF Heavyweight Championship]] against reigning champion [[Superstar Billy Graham]]. Rhodes won the first match on September 26 via countout,{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/videos/dusty-rhodes-vs-superstar-billy-graham-wwe-championship-match-september-26-1977-25056834 |title=DUSTY RHODES VS. "SUPERSTAR" BILLY GRAHAM: WWE CHAMPIONSHIP MATCH - SEPTEMBER 26, 1977 (4:53) |publisher=WWE |accessdate=June 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150524120144/http://www.wwe.com/videos/dusty-rhodes-vs-superstar-billy-graham-wwe-championship-match-september-26-1977-25056834 |archivedate=May 24, 2015 |df= }}{{cite book|title=The History of Professional Wrestling: The Results WWF 1963–1989|last=Cawthon|first=Graham|pages=222|publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|year=2013|isbn=978-1-4928-2597-5}} and lost the second, a [[Professional wrestling match types#Last Man Standing match|Texas Death match]], on October 24.{{cite book|title=The History of Professional Wrestling: The Results WWF 1963–1989|last=Cawthon|first=Graham|pages=224|publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|year=2013|isbn=978-1-4928-2597-5}} Graham won after a mid-ring collision, falling on Rhodes for the three count.{{cite book|title=Wrestling's Greatest Moments|author=Rickard, Mike|publisher=ECW Press|chapter=Superstar vs Superstar|year=2008|isbn=9781554903313}} === Jim Crockett Promotions (1985–1989) === [[File:Dusty Rhodes Bionic Elbow.jpg|thumb|Rhodes battling [[Harley Race]] at an NWA event]] He eventually began working as a [[Glossary of professional wrestling#Book|booker]] and wrestler with [[Jim Crockett Promotions]] (JCP) in the Mid-Atlantic, which eventually purchased [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW), formerly Georgia Championship Wrestling. Rhodes also teamed with [[Magnum T.A.]] as "America's Team", who opposed the [[The Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)|Four Horsemen]] and [[The Russian Team]] in 1985. They were one of the more dominant tag teams in the promotion until 1986, when Magnum's career was ended in a car accident. Subsequently, he teamed with [[Nikita Koloff]] as [[The Super Powers]]. Rhodes was also a two time [[NWA World Six-Man Tag Team Championship|World Six-Man Tag Team Champion]] with [[The Road Warriors]]. Rhodes had [[Feud (professional wrestling)|feuds]] with [[Abdullah the Butcher]], Pak Song, [[Terry Funk]], [[Kevin Sullivan (wrestler)|Kevin Sullivan]], [[Blackjack Mulligan]], Nikita Koloff, [[Harley Race]], Superstar Billy Graham, [[Ray Stevens (wrestler)|"Crippler" Ray Stevens]] and, most notably, [[Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)|The Four Horsemen]] (especially [[Ric Flair]] and [[Tully Blanchard]]). Rhodes, Flair and Race fought each other many times over the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship]]. Rhodes won the NWA World Heavyweight Championship three times; twice by defeating Race and once by defeating Flair.{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/sports/news/wrestling-icon-dusty-rhodes-dead-at-69-20150611|title=Dusty Rhodes, Wrestling Icon, Dead at 69|publisher=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=June 11, 2015|accessdate=June 12, 2015|author=Montgomery, James}} In October 1985, during his feud with Flair, Rhodes gave an interview that became known as his "Hard Times" promo,{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/story/_/id/13060411/dusty-rhodes-connected-fans-no-other-pro-wrestling-superstar|title=Dusty Rhodes was unlike any other pro wrestling superstar|author=Campbell, Brian|date=June 12, 2015|accessdate=June 12, 2015|publisher=ESPN}} arguably his most popular [[Promos (professional wrestling)|promo]]: :''"First of all, I would to thank the many, many fans throughout this country that wrote cards and letters to Dusty Rhodes, The American Dream, while I was down. Secondly, I want to thank [[Jim Crockett Promotions]] for waitin’ and takin’ the time ‘cause I know how important it was, [[Starrcade (1985)|Starrcade '85]] it is to the wrestling fans, it is to Jim Crockett promotions, and Dusty Rhodes The American Dream. With that wait, I got what I wanted, [[Ric Flair]] the World's Heavyweight Champion. I don’t have to say a whole lot more about the way I feel about Ric Flair; no respect, no honor. There is no honor amongst thieves in the first place.'' :''He put hard times on Dusty Rhodes and his family. You don’t know what hard times are, daddy. Hard times are when the textile workers around this country are out of work, they got four or five kids and can’t pay their wages, can’t buy their food. Hard times are when the auto workers are out of work and they tell ‘em to go home. And hard times are when a man has worked at a job for thirty years, thirty years, and they give him a watch, kick him in the butt and say "hey a computer took your place, daddy", that's hard times! That's hard times! And Ric Flair you put hard times on this country by takin’ Dusty Rhodes out, that's hard times. And we all had hard times together, and I admit, I don’t look like the athlete of the day supposed to look. My belly's just a lil’ big, my heiny's a lil’ big, but brother, I am bad. And they know I’m bad.'' :''There were two bad people… One was [[John Wayne]] and he's dead brother, and the other's right here. Nature Boy Ric Flair, the [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship|World's Heavyweight title]] belongs to these people. I’mma reach out right now, I want you at home to know my hand is touchin’ your hand for the gathering of the biggest body of people in this country, in this universe, all over the world now, reachin’ out because the love that was given me and this time I will repay you now. Because I will be the next World's Heavyweight Champion of this hard time blues. Dusty Rhodes tour, ‘85.'' :''And Ric Flair, Nature Boy… Let me leave you with this. One way to hurt Ric Flair, is to take what he cherishes more than anything in the world and that's the World's Heavyweight title. I’m gon’ take it, I been there twice. This time when I take it daddy, I’m gon’ take it for you. Let's gather for it. Don’t let me down now, ‘cause I came back for you, for [[Jim Crockett|that man upstairs that died 10-12 years ago]] and never got the opportunity to see a real World's Champion. And I’m proud of you, thank God I have you, and I love you. Love ya!"''.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9py4aMK3aIU|title=Dusty Rhodes talks about "hard times": Mid-Atlantic Wrestling, Oct. 29, 1985|first=|last=WWE|date=April 9, 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}}{{cite web|url=https://genius.com/Dusty-rhodes-hard-times-promo-annotated|title=Dusty Rhodes – Hard Times Promo|website=Genius}} The promo—which references out-of-work steel workers, factory runners and other blue-collar individuals—apparently resonated with wrestling fans so much that people came to him in arenas in tears to thank him for "honoring their plight". In 2015, an ESPN article referred to "Hard Times" as Rhodes' best interview, writing, "In just over three minutes, Rhodes fully encapsulated every ounce of his charm by endearing himself to blue-collar mid-America". During his stint as booker, JCP were engulfed in aggressive competition with the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF). When the WWF introduced [[Virgil (wrestler)|Mike Jones]] as [[Ted DiBiase]]'s bodyguard, [[Bobby Heenan]] suggested to name the character ''Virgil'' as an inside joke on Dusty's real name.{{cite book|title=Ted DiBiase: The Million Dollar Man|page=156|author=DiBiase, Ted with Tom Caiazzo|publisher=Pocket Books|year=2008|isbn=978-1-4165-5890-3}} Also in the late 1980s, Rhodes became synonymous with what would become known as the "[[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#D|Dusty finish]]", a trick ending where a wrestler would win a match while the referee was knocked out, and the decision would be overturned. Rhodes is often considered to be one of the most innovative and creative bookers in the history of professional wrestling. As previously mentioned, his work in the development of "supercards" and [[gimmick (professional wrestling)|gimmick]] matches did much to enhance the quality of entertainment and move the industry forward, as evident by other major promotions following with their own major cards and gimmicks. At the same time, however, he and JCP had an "old school" philosophy that did not bode well with the changes that were brought with fast moving media such as cable TV, etc. The long-standing [[Angle (professional wrestling)|storylines]] and the frequent use of the aforementioned "Dusty finish", techniques that had worked well during the NWA's territorial days, had now started to leave many fans dissatisfied with the promotion's booking.{{cite web|url=http://grantland.com/features/the-art-dusty-finish-cm-punk-reference-wrestling-lore-wwe-night-champions-event/|title=CM Punk’s Nostalgia Reign and the Art of the Dusty Finish|first=David|last=Shoemaker|date=September 19, 2012|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VvCSjVhDKbg|title=KICKSTARTER DUSTY FINISH/JIM CROCKETT DOCUMENTARY|first=|last=ellbowproduction|date=April 17, 2013|publisher=|via=YouTube}} Rhodes was fired after [[Starrcade (1988)|Starrcade '88]], because of a taboo on-screen bloodletting (laid down by the [[Turner Broadcasting System]] following their purchase of the company) during a November 26 altercation with [[The Road Warriors]].{{cite book|title=Wrestlecrap and Figure Four Weekly Present...The Death of WCW|last1=Reynolds|first1=R. D.|last2=Alvarez|first2=Bryan|pages=33–34|isbn=1-55022-661-4|publisher=ECW Press|year=2004}} Furious with the interference, Rhodes booked a storyline where [[Road Warrior Animal]] pulled a spike out of his shoulder pad and jammed it in Rhodes' eye, causing a severe laceration. Rhodes was then fired from WCW. Following this, Rhodes returned to Florida to compete in [[Championship Wrestling from Florida]] (CWF), where he captured the PWF Heavyweight Championship and also returned to the AWA for a few appearances. === World Wrestling Federation (1989–1991) === In mid-1989, Rhodes came to the WWF as the yellow [[Polka dot|polka-dotted]] "[[Average Joe|Common Man]]" Dusty Rhodes, a gimmick some felt was intended to humiliate him due to his synonymy with the rival JCP/WCW.{{cite book|title=Sex, Lies, and Headlocks|author1=Assael, Shaun |author2=Mike Mooneyham|publisher=Crown Publishers|year=2002|isbn=0609606905|pages=103–104}} Rhodes was introduced to WWF audiences through a series of vignettes where he would gregariously and enthusiastically perform working class roles (including that of a [[plumber]], [[Butcher|butcher's]] [[Apprenticeship|apprentice]], [[Filling station attendant|gas station attendant]], and [[Pizza delivery|pizza delivery man]]), eventually being recognized by others at the end of the skit ("Hey! Aren't you...?"). He was managed by [[Juanita Wright|Sapphire]], who was intended to represent the "common woman".{{cite book|title=Dusty: Reflections of an American Dream|last1=Rhodes|first1=Dusty|last2=Brody|first2=Howard|pages=127–128|year=2005|isbn=1-58261-907-7|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC}} During his early time in the WWF, Rhodes was embroiled in a heated storyline with "Macho King" [[Randy Savage]] and his manager/partner [[Sherri Martel|Sensational Queen Sherri]], who in turn found a rival in Sapphire. After a confrontation between the two couples, Savage's ex-manager [[Miss Elizabeth]] allied herself with Rhodes and Sapphire and was instrumental in helping them win the WWF's first mixed tag-team match during [[WrestleMania VI]]. Sapphire, however, left Rhodes during [[SummerSlam (1990)|SummerSlam]] for The Million Dollar Man's money. Afterwards, Rhodes dropped the polka dots and feuded with Dibiase and Virgil, which also resulted in the national debut of his son [[Goldust|Dustin]] at the [[Royal Rumble (1991)|1991 Royal Rumble]]. Both departed the WWF shortly after, marking the end of Rhodes' career as a full-time in-ring competitor. === Return to WCW and ECW (1991–2001) === Rhodes returned to WCW in 1991 as a member of WCW's booking committee, making his first appearance only 11 days after his last WWF appearance at the Royal Rumble. Booking disagreements between Rhodes and [[Ric Flair]] led to the latter's return to the WWF and [[Big Gold Belt#"Real" World Champion|the Big Gold Belt controversy]]. Rhodes also served as the on-screen [[Manager (professional wrestling)|manager]] of [[Ron Simmons]] from 1991 to 1992 and was in Simmons' corner on August 2, 1992 when he defeated [[Big Van Vader]] to win the [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship]]. He later joined the broadcast team, usually working with [[Tony Schiavone]] on ''[[WCW Saturday Night|Saturday Night]]''. He was paired with Schiavone and [[Bobby Heenan]] on pay-per-views. Rhodes was originally on the side of WCW when its battle with the [[New World Order (professional wrestling)|New World Order]] (nWo) began in 1996. At [[Souled Out (1998)|Souled Out 1998]], [[Larry Zbyszko]] asked Rhodes, who was working the PPV broadcast, to accompany him to the ring for his match against [[Scott Hall]]. Zbyszko won the match by disqualification due to interference by [[Louie Spicolli]]. Rhodes entered the ring, delivering his trademark elbow smashes to Spicolli as Zbyszko stood and grabbed Hall. Rhodes went to elbow Hall, but seemingly inadvertently hit Zbyszko instead turning [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heel]] in the process. Hall then pointed to Rhodes as he revealed an nWo shirt. The three began to drop repeated elbows on Zbyszko before Rhodes announced "That's tradition, WCW! Bite this!". Announcer Tony Schiavone left the broadcast booth in shock, but later returned [[Kayfabe|ripping]] Rhodes for his actions for most of the rest of the night. As a member of the nWo, Rhodes served as the manager of Hall [[The Outsiders (professional wrestling)|and]] [[Kevin Nash|Nash]]. This lasted until the November 30, 1998 episode of Monday Nitro, when Rhodes, who was guest refereeing a match between Barry Windham and [[Dean Malenko]] after being appointed by [[Eric Bischoff]], defected back to WCW by disqualifying Windham and awarding the match to Malenko. Bischoff then fired Rhodes. He left WCW in 2000 and went to [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]] (ECW) where he put over former [[ECW World Heavyweight Championship|ECW World Champion]], "King of Old School" [[Steve Corino]]. Rhodes returned once more to WCW, re-igniting his feud with [[Ric Flair]]. === Turnbuckle Championship Wrestling and other promotions (2000–2003) === After both WCW and ECW were bought by WWE (WWF), Rhodes went to compete in his own promotion, [[Turnbuckle Championship Wrestling]] with ex-WCW and ECW superstars in the Georgia, Florida and Tennessee. During this time he feuded with [[Terry Funk]] and Steve Corino in other territories. In 2002, Rhodes competed in Pro Pain Pro Wreslting based in Philadelphia feuding with [[Kevin Sullivan (wrestler)|Kevin Sullivan]]. This would lead to a Texas Bullrope match on November 23 in which Rhodes defeated Sullivan. === Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (2003–2005) === Rhodes began appearing with [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] (TNA) in 2003, returning to the ring to feud against the villainous [[Sports Entertainment Xtreme]] faction. on the January 15 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes, Road Warriors and Jeff Jarrett lost to [[Vince Russo]] and [[Triple X (professional wrestling)|Triple X]]. on the January 22 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes called out Nikita Koloff to reform the Superpowers, but Nikita turns on him. On the February 26 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes and [[Big Van Vader|Vader]] defeated [[Don and Ron Harris]] by disqualification. On the March 19 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes, Jeff Jarrett and D-Lo Brown defeated [[Erik Watts]], [[Brian Lawler]] and [[David Flair]] in a six-man tag team match a week later Rhodes defeated David Flair in a Bunkhouse match. On the April 9 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes defeated Brian Lawler in a [[Ladder match]]. On the August 13 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes and [[America's Most Wanted (professional wrestling)|America's Most Wanted]] defeated [[Disco Inferno (wrestler)|Glenn Gilbertti]] and [[Simon and Swinger|Simon Diamond and Johnny Swinger]] the following week Rhodes lost a bullrope to Glen Gilbertti after Christopher Daniels interfered. On the October 1 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes and Jarrett defeated [[A.J. Styles]] and Russo. The following week Rhodes got a shot at the NWA title against Styles but lost when he passed out during the figure-4. On the October 15 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes and America's Most Wanted defeated Legend, Sonny Siaki and Ekmo Fatu. On the November 26 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes and Jarrett wrestled to a no contest in a Lumberjack Fan Strap match. After taking a few months off Rhodes returned on May 19, 2004 where he and [[James Storm]] defeated [[Lance Hoyt|Dallas]] and [[Kid Kash]] in a “Bunkhouse Brawl” this led to the duo getting a shot at the [[NWA World Tag Team Championship]] on June 2 but they failed to win the titles. On the June 4 episode of Impact, Rhodes gave an interview with Mike Tenay but got punked out by NWA champ Jeff Jarrett. On the July 14 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes, [[Larry Zbyszko]] and [[3Live Kru]] defeated Jarrett, [[Ken Shamrock]], [[Hernandez (wrestler)|Hernandez]], [[Chad Collyer]] and [[Kyle McNeely|Onyx]]. On the August 25 NWATNA PPV, Russo suspended Rhodes from TNA and banned him from the Asylum a few days later on the August 27 episode of Impact, Rhodes showed up in the front row, and got attacked by Scott D’Amore and ejected again. On the September 1 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes under a mask billed as Midnight Rider teamed with [[Konnan]] and [[Road Dogg|B.G. James]] to defeat [[Team Canada (TNA)|Team Canada]] ([[Eric Young (wrestler)|Eric Young]] and [[Bobby Roode]] and [[Johnny Devine]]). On the September 8 NWATNA PPV, Rhodes defeated [[Scott D'Amore]] with Russo as the special guest referee. On the October 29 episode of Impact, Rhodes started his campaign to replace Vince Russo as the Director of Authority. Later, he became the [[Professional wrestling authority figures#Directors of Authority|Director of Authority]] at their November 7, 2004 [[pay-per-view]], [[Victory Road (2004)|Victory Road]].{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/PPVReports/2004/11/08/723409.html|author=Clevett, Jason|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|title=Victory Road bombs|accessdate=June 12, 2015}} At the same time, Rhodes acted as head [[Glossary of professional wrestling#Book|booker]] and writer. On the April 8, 2005 episode of Impact, Rhodes made the on-air decision to make all matches at Lockdown PPV in Six Sides of Steel. Then on the April 29 episode of Impact, Rhodes announced that MMA fighter [[Tito Ortiz]] will referee the World title match at [[Hard Justice (2005)]]. In May 2005, TNA President [[Dixie Carter (wrestling)|Dixie Carter]] asked Rhodes to move onto a creative team, which included [[Jeremy Borash]], Bill Banks, and [[Scott D'Amore]]. Rhodes resigned as booker, waiting out the rest of his contract with TNA, which expired soon after. === Independent circuit (2003–2006) === [[File:Dusty-kid XII.jpg|thumb|left|Rhodes facing [[Kid Kash]] in Ballpark Brawl]] Rhodes made his first indy circuit appearance on April 12, 2003 for [[Ring of Honor]] (ROH), when he participated in the "I Quit Bunkhouse Riot" as a member of [[Homicide (wrestler)|Homicide]]'s team.{{cite web|publisher=Ring of Honor|url=http://www.rohwrestling.com/content/exclusive-ringside-content|title=Exclusive Ringside Content|date=November 8, 2012|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}{{cite web|publisher=Ring of Honor|url=http://www.rohwrestling.com/content/2003-ring-honor-results|title=2003 Ring of Honor Results|accessdate=June 14, 2015}} On December 12, Rhodes defeated [[Jerry Lawler]] at an International Wrestling Cartel show that also featured [[Mick Foley]] as the special guest referee.{{cite web|title=2003 Results|publisher=International Wrestling Cartel|url=http://www.iwcwrestling.com/results/2003.html|accessdate=June 14, 2015}} Rhodes returned to ROH on March 13, 2004, where he competed alongside [[The Carnage Crew]] in a Scramble Cage match against Special K, which the Carnage Crew won. On July 24, Rhodes returned to Full Impact Pro (FIP) and defeated [[Gangrel (wrestler)|Gangrel]]. In October, he appeared for Northeast Wrestling in a victory over [[Kamala (wrestler)|Kamala]]. Later in the month, he appeared for [[IWA Mid-South]] in a tag team match with [[Ian Rotten]] in a victory over [[Chris Candido]] and Steve Stone. Rhodes made three appearances for the Japanese promotion [[HUSTLE]] in 2004,{{cite book|title=Dusty: Reflections of Wrestling's American Dream|author1=Rhodes, Dusty |author2=Howard Brody |author3=George Steinbrenner |last-author-amp=yes |publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc.|year=2013|isbn=9781613212448}} the first being on January 4 in a six-man tag team match with Steve Corino and [[Tom Howard (wrestler)|Tom Howard]] against [[Mil Mascaras]], [[Dos Caras]], and [[Sicodelico Jr.]], which Rhodes' team lost. The second was on March 7, where he teamed with his son Dustin against [[Shinjiro Otani]] and [[Satoshi Kojima]], which he also lost. The third was on May 8, where he defeated Corino. Starting in December 2004, Rhodes made regular appearances for Carolina Championship Wrestling (CCW), where his first match for the promotion saw him team up with [[The Rock 'n' Roll Express]] to take on [[Dennis Condrey]], [[Bobby Eaton]], and [[Stan Lane]], all three of the best-known members of the [[The Midnight Express (professional wrestling)|Midnight Express]].{{cite book|title=Dusty: Reflections of Wrestling's American Dream|author1=Rhodes, Dusty |author2=Howard Brody |author3=George Steinbrenner |last-author-amp=yes |publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc.|year=2013|isbn=9781613212448|chapter=14}} He also briefly resurrected his feud with Tully Blanchard in CCW, earning two consecutive victories over him, the second being in a Bunkhouse Brawl. On April 9, 2005, Rhodes challenged Jeff Jarrett (who was still contracted to TNA, but due to TNA's then-affiliation with the NWA, he was allowed to appear for other affiliated promotions) for the NWA World Heavyweight Championship. In a match that featured [[Jimmy Valiant]] as the special guest referee, Jarrett retained the title after [[Terry Funk]] made a surprise appearance and interfered. This led to Rhodes challenging Funk to a Falls-Count-Anywhere Bunkhouse match, which Rhodes won. This would be Rhodes' final appearance with CCW until August, where he would team with his son Dustin against [[Phi Delta Slam]]. On July 15, 2005, Rhodes participated in Ballpark Brawl IV in a victory over [[Kid Kash]].{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2005/07/21/1141216.html|date=July 21, 2005|accessdate=June 12, 2015|title=Buffalo BallPark Brawl bats .400|publisher=Canadian Online Explorer|work=SLAM! Wrestling|first=Chris|last=Sokol}} Rhodes participated in the first [[WrestleReunion]], competing in an eight-man tag team match with [[D'Lo Brown]], [[The Blue Meanie]], and [[Tom Prichard]] against Steve Corino, [[Test (wrestler)|Andrew Martin]], Evil Clown, and the Masked Superstar. Rhodes faced Tully Blanchard at a ''Starrcade'' Tribute Show on November 19, where he was managed by [[Magnum T.A.]] and where Blanchard was managed by [[James J. Dillon]]. Rhodes ended up losing the match.{{Cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Other_News_4/article_11718.shtml|title=WrestleReunion Night 1 – Dusty Rhodes, Roddy Piper, Jake "The Snake", Mick Foley|author=Burgan, Derek|date=January 29, 2005|accessdate=June 15, 2015|publisher=[[Pro Wrestling Torch]]}} On December 3, 2005, Rhodes returned to Carolina Championship Wrestling for one night only to face Terry Funk in an [["I Quit" match]], which Rhodes won. Rhodes made his final major appearances on the independent circuit before returning full-time to WWE in mid-2006, defeating Jerry Lawler by disqualification at a Southern Championship Wrestling (SCW) show and also earning a victory over Steve Corino in a Texas Bullrope match for Big Time Wrestling. === Return to WWE (2005–2015) === [[File:Dusty Rhodes.jpg|thumb|Rhodes at the 2009 [[WWE Hall of Fame]] ceremony, inducting the Funk Brothers]] [[File:Flickr - simononly - WWE Hall of Fame 2012 - The Four Horsemen.jpg|thumb|Rhodes at the 2012 [[WWE Hall of Fame]] ceremony, inducting the Four Horsemen]] In September 2005, Rhodes signed a WWE Legends deal and was brought onto the [[Glossary of professional wrestling#Book|Creative Team]] as a creative consultant. He made an appearance on the October 3, 2005 ''[[WWE Raw|WWE Raw Homecoming]]'' in which he, along with other legends, beat down [[Rob Conway]], to whom Rhodes delivered a signature ''[[Professional wrestling attacks#Bionic elbow|Bionic Elbow]]''.{{cite web|title=A Stunning Homecoming|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/10032005/|publisher=WWE}} Rhodes made an appearance on the June 19, 2006 episode of ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'', appearing in a backstage segment with [[Vince McMahon]] where he promoted his new DVD, ''The American Dream – The Dusty Rhodes Story''. A few weeks before [[Survivor Series (2006)|Survivor Series]], Rhodes returned to WWE to be a part of Team WWE Legends, led by Flair. The team, which consisted of Sgt. Slaughter, Ron Simmons, and Arn Anderson (acting as manager) competed against [[The Spirit Squad]] at Survivor Series.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/2006/matches/333248013/results/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227150840/http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/2006/matches/333248013/results/|archivedate=February 27, 2009|title=Legendary survivor|date=November 26, 2006|last=Starr|first=Noah|accessdate=June 7, 2011|publisher=[[WWE]]}} Rhodes was inducted into the [[WWE Hall of Fame]] on March 31, 2007 by his two sons, [[Goldust|Dustin]] and [[Cody Rhodes|Cody]].{{cite web|title=Rhodes finds peace of mind|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/halloffame/dustyrhodes/interview}} During his acceptance speech, Rhodes asked Ric Flair and [[Arn Anderson]] to hold up the "sign" and induct him and [[Harley Race]] into the [[The Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)|Four Horsemen]]. He has also inducted several other people into the Hall of Fame, including his mentor [[Eddie Graham]] in 2008, The Funk Brothers ([[Terry Funk|Terry]] and [[Dory Funk Jr.]]) in 2009, [[The Road Warriors]] in 2011, and longtime rivals [[The Four Horsemen (professional wrestling)|The Four Horsemen]] in 2012. A few weeks before WWE's 2007 broadcast of [[The Great American Bash (2007)|The Great American Bash]], Rhodes returned to WWE television to feud with [[Randy Orton]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/07022007/|title=A matter of time|date=July 2, 2007|last=Rote|first=Andrew|accessdate=December 31, 2007|publisher=WWE}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/07092007/|title=Bulldozed in the Bayou|date=July 9, 2007|last=DiFino|first=Lennie|accessdate=December 31, 2007|publisher=WWE}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/07162007/articles/rhodesangeratorton|title=Orton's audacity further fuels Rhodes’ anger|date=July 16, 2007|last=Clayton|first=Corey|accessdate=December 31, 2007|publisher=WWE}} At The Great American Bash, Orton defeated Rhodes in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Strap match|Texas Bullrope match]] after hitting Rhodes with a cowbell.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/thegreatamericanbash/history/2007/matches/42789822/results/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090223043744/http://www.wwe.com/shows/thegreatamericanbash/history/2007/matches/42789822/results/|archivedate=February 23, 2009|title=A Great American Nightmare|date=July 22, 2007|last=Dee|first=Louie |accessdate=June 7, 2011|publisher=[[WWE]]}} The following night on ''Raw'', after Orton defeated Rhodes' son Cody, Orton delivered a kick to Rhodes' head while he was trying to tend to his son.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/07232007/|title=One bad apple leads to Dominator destruction|date=July 23, 2007 |last=Clayton |first=Corey |accessdate=December 31, 2007|publisher=WWE}} On December 10, 2007, on the ''Raw'' [[Chris Benoit Memorial Show|15th Anniversary special episode]], Rhodes was at ringside to see Cody and [[Bob Holly|Hardcore Holly]] defeat [[Lance Cade and Trevor Murdoch]] for the [[World Tag Team Championship (WWE)|World Tag Team Championship]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/12102007/|title=Rhodes and Holly golden on Raw's 15th Anniversary|last=Clayton|first=Corey|date=December 10, 2007|accessdate=December 31, 2007|publisher=WWE}} On August 31, 2009, during the time Cody was part of [[The Legacy (professional wrestling)|The Legacy]] with Randy Orton and [[Ted DiBiase Jr.|Ted DiBiase]], Rhodes was the special guest host of ''Raw'' and booked a match between Cody and Orton for Orton's WWE Championship with [[John Cena]] as the special guest [[Referee (professional wrestling)|referee]]. It quickly turned out to be a ruse with Dusty's intention to allow Legacy to attack Cena, as well as [[D-Generation X]] ([[Triple H]] and [[Shawn Michaels]]) once they came to make the save. Despite the four standing tall together, Orton quickly gave an RKO to Rhodes, and though initially angered, Cody fell in line behind Orton.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/08312009/mainarticle|title=American Nightmare|last=Sitterson|first=Aubrey|date=August 31, 2009|publisher=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]]|accessdate=January 7, 2010}} On July 9, 2010, Rhodes wrestled the final match of his career at an [[Florida Championship Wrestling|FCW]] live event, where he teamed up with Cody and Goldust to defeat the team of [[Caylen Croft]], [[Curt Hawkins]], & [[Trent Barreta]] in a 6-man tag team match.http://profightdb.com/cards/fcw/kissimmee-show-incomplete-card-25431.html Rhodes was the head writer and creative director for the weekly ''[[WWE NXT (TV series)|NXT Wrestling]]'' television broadcast. On September 12, 2013, he was removed as NXT Commissioner. Rhodes made his return to ''Raw'' on September 16, 2013 after accepting a "business proposition" from [[Stephanie McMahon]] in an attempt for WWE to rehire both his sons Cody and Dustin. After learning that McMahon would only rehire one son of his choosing, Rhodes turned down the offer and was subsequently knocked out by [[Big Show]] on the orders of McMahon.{{cite web|author=Benigno, Anthony|date=September 16, 2013|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/2013-09-16/wwe-raw-results-26148930/page-4|title=Raw results: While Dusty falls, Bryan rises above the corporate 'Game'|publisher=WWE|accessdate=May 10, 2014}} Rhodes also appeared at [[Battleground (2013)|Battleground]] in the corner of Cody and Goldust as they took on [[The Shield (professional wrestling)|The Shield]] ([[Seth Rollins]] and [[Roman Reigns]] with [[Dean Ambrose]] at ringside) in a tag team match.{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2013/10/06/21176466.html|title=Battle may be over but WWE Battleground still leaves unresolved issues|author=Asher, Matthew|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=June 12, 2015}} The stipulation of the match would be that if the [[Gold and Stardust|Rhodes Family]] won, Cody and Goldust got their jobs with the company back, but if they lose Dusty would be fired as an NXT trainer and none of them could appear on WWE programming ever again. The Rhodes brothers won the match, thus reinstating them to the roster and allowing Dusty to retain his position in NXT. During the match, Dusty got into an altercation with Ambrose and performed the ''Bionic Elbow'' on him. Rhodes appeared on the February 16, 2015 episode of ''Raw'', in an effort to reunite Goldust and Stardust, who were engaged in a conflict. Rhodes appeared at [[Fastlane (2015)|Fastlane]] on February 22, in a backstage segment with Goldust. Rhodes' final appearance on WWE programming would be on March 28, when he appeared on the Hall of Fame: Live From the Red Carpet show. == Personal life == Runnels was married to Sandra from 1965 to 1975. In 1978 he married Michelle Rubio; the couple were married for 37 years until his death in 2015. He had four children: [[Goldust|Dustin]], Kristin, Teil and [[Cody Rhodes|Cody Runnels]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dallascowboyscheerleaders.com/history/watn.cfm?id=1477AB1D-0234-28D0-025A70ED93BAB9EA|title=Kickin' It Up With... Kristin Ditto|accessdate=June 27, 2009|publisher=[[Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090628080849/http://www.dallascowboyscheerleaders.com/history/watn.cfm?id=1477AB1D-0234-28D0-025A70ED93BAB9EA|archivedate=June 28, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/article/20120617/PC20/120619214|title=Cody Rhodes follows famous father's footsteps|author=Mooneyham, Mike|publisher=The Post and Courier|accessdate=June 12, 2015|date=June 17, 2012}} He had five grandchildren; Dakota, the daughter of Dustin and his ex-wife, [[Terri Runnels|Terri Boatright]],{{cite web|url=http://www.charleston.net/news/2008/nov/30/wrestling_diva_woman_all_seasons/ |title=Wrestling diva a woman for all seasons |last=Mooneyham |first=Mike |publisher=The Post and Courier |accessdate=December 25, 2008 |date=November 30, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204105815/http://www.charleston.net/news/2008/nov/30/wrestling_diva_woman_all_seasons/ |archivedate=December 4, 2008 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/Reviews/2008/11/10/7368106.html|title=Terri Runnels reveals brain, not body, in shoot DVD|last=Dean Johnson|first=Steven|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=December 26, 2008|date=November 16, 2008}} Dalton and Dylan, children of Kristin and her husband Don Ditto, and Kellan and Maris, children of Teil and her husband Kevin Gergel.{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/tbo/obituary.aspx?n=virgil-runnels&pid=175078194|title=Virgil Runnels Jr.|accessdate=June 14, 2015|website=[[Legacy.com]]}} He also had a brother, Larry, and a sister, Connie. === Illness and death === In his later years, Rhodes developed [[kidney failure]].{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2015/06/11/22447606.html|title="The American Dream" Dusty Rhodes dies|author=Oliver, Greg|publisher=SLAM! Wrestling|accessdate=June 12, 2015|date=June 10, 2015}} On June 10, 2015, paramedics responded to Rhodes' home in [[Orlando, Florida]], after getting a call reporting that he had fallen. They drove him to a nearby hospital, where he died the next day. Rhodes was [[Cremation|cremated]] after his death, and his ashes were spread in November 2015 by his son Dustin on a ranch that Rhodes loved to visit.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestlinginc.com/wi/news/2015/1130/604292/goldust-on-spreading-dusty-rhodes-ashes/|title=Goldust On Spreading Dusty Rhodes' Ashes, WWE Cyber Monday Sales, Xavier Woods Previews Game|publisher=Wrestling Inc.|first=Marc|last=Middleton|date=November 30, 2015|accessdate=December 6, 2015}} At the [[Money in the Bank (2015)|2015 Money in the Bank]] pay-per-view event, a [[ten-bell salute]] was given in honor of Rhodes, with the entire WWE roster and the McMahon family on the entrance ramp. The next night on ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'', they honored him with a video tribute and a special after Raw on the [[WWE Network]]. At the ''[[WWE NXT (TV series)|NXT]]'' tapings following his death, he was honored with another ten-bell salute. ==Legacy== In August 2015, WWE's [[NXT (WWE brand)|NXT]] introduced the [[Dusty Rhodes Tag Team Classic]], a [[tag team]] tournament in honor of Rhodes.{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|url=https://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wwenxtreport/article_87100.shtml|title=James's WWE "NXT TakeOver: Brooklyn" Report 8/22: Balor vs. Owens ladder match for NXT Title, epic Women's match, Tag Titles, Samoa Joe, Liger, dignitaries in the crowd; Overall Reax|date=August 22, 2015|accessdate=June 27, 2018|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|publisher=TDH Communications Inc.}} The tournament has been held annually since, with three editions having taken place as of April 2018.{{cite web|last=Coyle|first=Sean|url=http://www.espn.com/wwe/story/_/id/22690442/wwe-nxt-results-aleister-black-steps-next-nxt-title-challenger-dusty-rhodes-tag-team-classic-begins-tommaso-ciampa-returns|title=Aleister Black earns NXT title shot, Authors of Pain kick off Dusty Classic with win, Ciampa returns|date=March 8, 2018|accessdate=June 27, 2018|website=[[ESPN]]}} == Championships and accomplishments == {{multiple issues| {{no footnotes|date=April 2013}} {{primary sources|date=February 2008}} {{update|date=October 2014}} }} {{Infobox European political party |name = European National Front |party_logo = European National Front.png | president = [[Roberto Fiore]] | foundation = {{start date|2004|10|23|df=y}} |dissolution = 2009 | party_articletitle = European National Front | ideology = [[Ultranationalism]] (official)
[[Anti-capitalism]]
[[Anti-communism]]
[[Anti-globalisation]]
[[Anti-Zionism]]
[[Third position]] | position = [[Far-right]] | international = ''None'' | europarl = ''None'' | colours = [[Emerald (color)|Emerald]], [[Red (color)|red]], [[Black (color)|black]] | headquarters = | website = }} '''European National Front''' was a coordinating structure of European ultranationalist parties. There had been one elected [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] from ENF in the past. He was the leader of the Italian [[New Force (Italy)|New Force]], [[Roberto Fiore]]. Three parties of the European National Front are today included at the [[Alliance for Peace and Freedom]]. ==Structure== The European National Front is headed by General Secretary, elected by ENF Assembly. The current General Secretary is [[Roberto Fiore]]. The Political Council is the founder's staff of the ENF. It safeguards the idea and principles of ENF. The Council can be increased by unanimous will of cooptation. It represents the Front outside, and confirms applications for ENF membership. The Members of the Council belong to ENF Assembly. The ENF Assembly defines the tactics and strategy of ENF. The Assembly consists of representatives of the movements belonging to ENF and members of Political Council. The Co-ordination Centre executes the current tasks of ENF. It gathers information and propaganda, and co-ordinates ENF activities. Legal registered political parties/movements that accept the principles, aims and structure of ENF can apply for membership. The accession to ENF must be submitted by authorized representative of the applicant and then confirmed by Political Council. The representative of the Affiliated Group sits on the Assembly with advisory vote. The status of the Affiliated Group can be granted by Political Council. ===Member parties=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Country ! Party ! Abbr. |- | {{flag|France}} | [[Renouveau français|French Renewal]] | RF |- | {{flag|Germany}} | [[National Democratic Party of Germany]] | NPD |- | {{flag|Greece}} | [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] | XA |- | {{flag|Italy}} | [[New Force (Italy)|New Force]] | FN |- | {{flag|Poland}} | [[National Revival of Poland]] | NOP |- | {{flag|Romania}} | [[Noua Dreaptă|New Right]] | ND |- | {{flag|Spain}} | [[La Falange (1999)|FE/La Falange]] | FE |} === Affiliated groups === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Country ! Party |- |{{BUL}} |[[Bulgarian National Alliance]] |- |{{POR}} |[[National Renovator Party]] |} === Former affiliates === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Country ! Party |- |{{GRE}} |[[Patriotic Alliance (Greece)|Patriotic Alliance]] (party disbanded) |- |{{NED}} |[[National Alliance (Netherlands)|National Alliance]] (party disbanded) |- |{{UKR}} |[[All-Ukrainian Union "Svoboda"]] (party joined [[Alliance of European National Movements]] as observer) |} == See also == * [[Alliance for Peace and Freedom]] * [[Alliance of European National Movements]] * [[Euronat]] ==External links== *[http://www.nouadreapta.org/limbistraine.php?lmb=spa Developments and news-ENF] (Romanian language) {{EU_politics}} [[Category:Nationalist organizations]] [[Category:Pan-European political parties]] [[Category:Neo-fascism]] [[Category:Far-right politics in Europe]] [[Category:Far-right political parties]] [[Category:Third Position]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{unreferenced|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Exploring China: A Culinary Adventure | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Documentary film|Documentary]] | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = Emma Peach | creative_director = | presenter = [[Ching He Huang]]
[[Ken Hom]] | starring = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 4 | executive_producer = Paula Trafford | producer = Emma Peach | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 60 minutes | company = KEO Films | distributor = | channel = [[BBC Two]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = {{Start date|2012|8|5|df=y}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01lybfj }} '''''Exploring China: A Culinary Adventure''''' is a four-part British [[Documentary film|documentary]] television series that aired on [[BBC Two]]. Chefs [[Ken Hom]] and [[Ching He Huang]], both Chinese food specialists, describing their travels through China and the recipes and personal stories they find there.Hom and Huang will travel to Beijing, learning about Peking Duck, and on to the Silk Road, Kashgar, and the Sichuan Province, together bringing a unique and authoritative perspective on Chinese food that will surprise and inform.Ken and Ching undertake an epic 3000-mile culinary adventure across China - not only to reveal its food, but its people, history, culture and soul.BBC Books has acquired and published the title to accompany the BBC Two series of four hour-long episodes. ==External links== *{{BBC programme}} [[Category:BBC television documentaries]] [[Category:2010s British documentary television series]] [[Category:2010s British travel television series]] [[Category:2010s British cooking television series]] [[Category:2012 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:British cooking television programmes]] [[Category:Cookbooks]] [[Category:Food reality television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] {{BBC-tv-prog-stub}} {{documentary-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Adoption */ Added link by .nz to relevant stub page Unique_Domain_Authentication_Identifier
revision.text:
{{external links|date=January 2018}} The '''Extensible Provisioning Protocol''' ('''EPP''') is a flexible protocol designed for allocating objects within registries over the [[Internet]]. The motivation for the creation of EPP was to create a robust and flexible protocol that could provide communication between [[domain name registry|domain name registries]] and [[domain name registrar]]s. These transactions are required whenever a [[domain name]] is registered or renewed, thereby also preventing [[domain hijacking]]. Prior to its introduction, registries had no uniform approach, and many different proprietary interfaces existed. While its use for domain names was the initial driver, the protocol is designed to be usable for any kind of ordering and fulfilment system.
EPP is based on [[XML]] - a structured, text-based format. The underlying network transport is not fixed, although the only currently specified method is over [[Transmission Control Protocol|TCP]]. The protocol has been designed with the flexibility to allow it to use other transports such as [[BEEP]], [[SMTP]], or [[SOAP]].
The first protocol drafts were published as [[IETF]] individual submission [[Internet-Draft]] documents by Scott Hollenbeck of [[Verisign]] in November 2000: * [http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-hollenbeck-epp-00 Extensible Provisioning Protocol] * [http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-hollenbeck-epp-contact-00 Extensible Provisioning Protocol Contact Mapping] * [http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-hollenbeck-epp-domain-00 Extensible Provisioning Protocol Domain Name Mapping] * [http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-hollenbeck-epp-host-00 Extensible Provisioning Protocol Host Mapping] * [http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-hollenbeck-epp-tcp-00 Extensible Provisioning Protocol Transport Over TCP]
The individual submission documents were adopted by the [[IETF]] ''Provisioning Registry'' (''provreg'') [[working group]], which was created after a [[Birds of a feather (computing)|BoF]] session was held at [http://www.ietf.org/proceedings/49/00dec-36.htm#P5400_260270 IETF-49] in December 2000. Proposed Standard documents (RFCs 3730 - 3734) were published by the [[RFC Editor]] in March 2004. Draft Standard documents (RFCs 4930 - 4934) were published in May 2007. In August 2009 IETF granted EPP the status of full standard, [http://www.rfc-editor.org/std/std69.txt STD 69].
==Adoption== The protocol has been adopted by a number of domain name registries, such as: [[.ac]], [[.aero]], [[.ag]], [[.ai]], [[.asia]], [[.ar]], [[.at]], [[.au]], [[.be]], [[.biz]], [[.br]], [[.bz]], [[.ca]], [[.cat]], [[.cc]], [[.ch]], [[.cl]], [[.cn]], [[.co]], [[.cr]], [[.cz]], [[.com]], [[.coop]], [[.cx]], [[.cz]], [[.dk]], [[.ee]], [[.es]] (over HTTPS), [[.eu]], [[.fi]], [[.fm]], [[.fr]], [[.gr]] (over HTTPS), [[.gs]], [[.hn]], [[.ht]], [[.im]], [[.in]], [[.info]], [[.io]], [[.it]] (over HTTPS), [[.jobs]], [[.ke]], [[.ki]], [[.kz]], [[.la]], [[.lc]], [[.li]], [[.lt]], [[.lu]], [[.lv]], [[.md]], [[.me]], [[.mk]], [[.mn]], [[.mobi]], [[.ms]], [[.mu]], [[.mx]], [[.na]], [[.name]], [[.net]], [[.nf]], [[.ng]], [[.nl]], [[.no]], [[.nu]], [[.nz]] (EPP codes referred to as [[Unique_Domain_Authentication_Identifier|UDAIs]]), [[.org]], [[.pe]], [[.pk]], [[.pl]] (over HTTPS), [[.pro]], [[.ps]], [[.pt]], [[.ru]], [[.ro]], [[.sc]], [[.se]], [[.sh]], [[.si]], [[.su]], [[.tel]], [[.tl]], [[.tm]], [[.travel]], [[.tv]], [[.tw]], [[.ua]], [[.uk]], [[.us]], [[.vc]], [[.ve]] and [[.za]] as well as [[ENUM]] registries such as those operating the [http://www.enum.nl/ +31], +41, +43, +44 and +48 country codes.
[[Transfer secret|EPP authInfo "codes" or "keys"]] are also required in the transfer of generic top-level domain names between registrars ([[.com]], [[.net]], [[.org]], [[.biz]], [[.info]]).
.com and .net domain names only began requiring the EPP key from fourth quarter 2006.
==References== ===Related RFCs=== * RFC 3375 - Generic Registry-Registrar Protocol Requirements * RFC 3735 - Guidelines for Extending EPP * RFC 3915 - Domain Registry Grace Period Mapping (e.g. [[Add Grace Period]], [[Redemption Grace Period]]) * RFC 4114 - Using EPP for [[ENUM]] addresses * RFC 5910 - Domain Name System (DNS) Security Extensions Mapping for the Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) (obsoletes RFC 4310, [[DNSSEC]]) * RFC 5730 - Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) (obsoletes RFC 4930, which obsoleted RFC 3730) * RFC 5731 - Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) Domain Name Mapping (obsoletes RFC 4931) * RFC 5732 - Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) Host Mapping (obsoletes RFC 4932) * RFC 5733 - Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) Contact Mapping (obsoletes RFC 4933) * RFC 5734 - Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) Transport over TCP (obsoletes RFC 4934)
===Adoption=== * [http://www.ietf.org/iesg/implementation/report-rfc4930-4934.txt IETF Implementation Report for RFCs 4930-4934]. <!--Retrieved September 04, 2009.--> (This includes a list of top-level domain registries that have implemented EPP.)
[[Category:Domain name system]] [[Category:XML-based standards]]

'''Frederick A. de Armas''' is a literary scholar, critic and novelist who is currently [[Andrew W. Mellon]] Distinguished Service Professor in Humanities at the [[University of Chicago]].
==Biography== Frederick A. de Armas was born in Havana, Cuba on February 9, 1945. He attended elementary school at La Salle and when his parents moved to France, he went to boarding school at [[Le Rosey]] in Switzerland. After his family lost their possessions as a result of the [[Cuban Revolution]], he moved to the United States.<ref>See his autobiography included in a volume entitled ''¿Por qué España? Memorias del hispanismo estadounidense'', eds. Anna Caballe Masrorroll and Randolph D. Pope. Barcelona: Galaxia Gutenberg, 2015.</ref> De Armas holds a Ph.D. in Comparative Literature from the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] (1969), and has taught at [[Louisiana State University]] (1969–1988), [[Pennsylvania State University]] (where he was [[Edwin Erle Sparks]] Professor of Spanish and Comparative Literature) (1988–2000) and has been a visiting professor at [[Duke University]] (1994). Since 2000 he has been at the [[University of Chicago]] where he is [[Andrew W. Mellon]] Distinguished Service Professor in the Departments of Romance Languages and Literatures and Comparative Literature. He has served as Chair of Romance Languages and Literatures (2006–2009; 2010–2012). In addition he has been Vice President and President of the Cervantes Society of America (2003–2009); and President of AISO Asociacion Internacional Siglo de Oro (2015-2017).
==Career== De Armas' publications focus on early modern Spanish literature and culture, often from a comparative perspective. His interests include the politics of astrology, magic and the Hermetic tradition, [[ekphrasis]], verbal and visual culture, etc.<ref>Carrie L. Ruiz, "Oscillating trends: A Reflection of the Status of Seventeenth-Century Studies Today: Interview of Frederick A. de Armas" ''Transitions. Journal of Franco-Iberian Studies'' 5 (2009), pp. 9-25</ref> His early books evince an interest in the relationship between mythology and literature, between the classics and [[Spanish Golden Age]] works. They include: ''The Invisible Mistress: Aspects of Feminism and Fantasy in the Golden Age'' (1976), which contains some of the earliest discussions of proto-feminism in early modern Spain,<ref>''The Perception of Women in Spanish Theater of the Golden Age''. Ed. Anita K. Stoll and Dawn L. Smith. Lewisburg: Bucknell University Press, 1991, p. 19</ref> and ''The Return of Astraea: An Astral-Imperial Myth in Calderón'' (1986), which is one of the first studies that approach Calderón from a historicist perspective and is also deeply influenced by the writings of the [[Warburg Institute]].<ref>Santiago Fernández Mosquera, "El significado de las primeras fiestas cortesanas de Calderón," ''Calderón y el pensamiento ideológico y cultural de su época: XIV Coloquio Anglogermano sobre Calderón'', eds., Manfred Tietz y Gero Arnscheidt, Stuttgart, Steiner, 2008, p.224.</ref> For example, he interprets the figure of Circe in one of Calderon's plays as critiquing the policies of [[Philip IV of Spain|Philip IV]]'s minister, the Count-Duke of Olivares.<ref>Margaret Rich Greer, ''The Play of Power. Mythological Court Dramas of Calderón de la Barca.''Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1991, pp. 88ff.</ref> On the other hand, [[Astraea (mythology)|Astraea]] is in many cases a figure that serves to praise the regime. His interest in Golden Age Theater has led him to publish several book collections: ''The Prince in the Tower: Perceptions of "La vida es sueño"'' (1993), ''Heavenly Bodies: The Realms of "La estrella de Sevilla"'' (1996) and ''A Star-Crossed Golden Age: Myth and the Spanish Comedia'' (1998).
One of his main interests throughout his career has been the relationship between the verbal and the visual in early modern Spanish literature and Italian art. In recent years, this subject has become central to his research, as evinced by the book, ''Cervantes, Raphael and the Classics'' (Cambridge, 1998). This study focuses on [[Miguel de Cervantes|Cervantes’]] most famous tragedy, ''[[The Siege of Numantia|La Numancia]]'', showing how it is engaged in a conversation with classical authors of Greece and Rome, especially through the interpretations of antiquity presented by the artist [[Raphael]]. This book was followed by the collections ''Writing for the Eyes in the Spanish Golden Age'' (2004) and ''Ekphrasis in the Age of Cervantes'' (2005). In the introduction to this last collection he establishes a typology of [[ekphrasis]], including definitions for allusive, collectionist, descriptive, dramatic, interpolated, narrative, shaping, and veiled ekphrasis, as well as meta-ekphrasis and ur-ekphrasis. He applies these terms in his book: ''Quixotic Frescoes. Cervantes and Italian Art'' (Toronto, 2006).
After his book on Cervantes and Italian art, he co-edited two collections on Spanish Golden Age theater. The first one, on tragedy, is entitled ''Hacia la tragedia: Lecturas para un nuevo milenio'' (Madrid, 2008); and the second one, on a specific writer is called ''Calderón: del manuscrito a la escena'' (2011). At the same time, he continues to work on Cervantes, having published an edited volume, ''Ovid in the Age of Cervantes'' (2010). His latest book, ''Don Quixote among the Saracens: Clashes of Civilizations and Literary Genres'' (2011) has received the American Publishers' Association PROSE Award in Literature, Honorable Mention (2011). The book has a double focus. The first has to do with a [[clash of civilizations]] and asks: Why is [[Don Quixote]] at peace among the Saracens? The second has to do with Don Quixote as an "imperial" vehicle for the assimilation or destruction of literary genres.
Starting around 2008 De Armas became increasingly interested in the cultural and literary productions of the maternal side of his family, publishing essays on Ana Galdós, Domingo A. Galdós and [[Benito Pérez Galdós]]. He has also started to publish fiction while continuing to work on the literature and culture of early modern Spain. His novel, ''El abra del Yumuri'', takes place in Cuba during the last three months of 1958, just before the fall of [[Fulgencio Batista]] and the triumph of the [[Cuban Revolution]]. It focuses on the lives of five women, most of them from the upper bourgeoisie, and how they deal with political and social upheaval, as well as the dangers of a serial killer that preys on women of means. For some critics, the novel combines two very different trends: that of the social novel inspired by [[Benito Pérez Galdós]], and that of [[magic realism]] embodied by [[Alejo Carpentier]]. <ref> Jose María Pozuelo Yvancos, "El abra del Yumuri: La Habana antes del fin," ''ABC Cultural'', enero 2017. http://www.abc.es/cultura/cultural/abci-abra-yumuri-habana-antes-201701130220_noticia.html </ref>
==Bibliography== * ''The Four Interpolated Stories in the Roman Comique'' (Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 1971). * ''Paul Scarron'' (New York: Twayne Books, 1972). * ''The Invisible Mistress: Aspects of Feminism and Fantasy in the Golden Age'' (Charlottesville: Biblioteca Siglo de Oro, 1976). * ''The Return of Astraea: An Astral-Imperial Myth in Calderón'' (Lexington: University Press of Kentucky, 1986). * ''The Prince in the Tower: Perceptions of "La vida es sueño"'' (Lewisburg: Bucknell University Press, 1993). * ''Heavenly Bodies: The Realms of "La estrella de Sevilla"'' (Lewisburg: Bucknell University Press, 1996). * ''A Star-Crossed Golden Age: Myth and the Spanish Comedia'' (Lewisburg: Bucknell University Press, 1998). * ''Cervantes, Raphael and the Classics'' (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1998). * ''European Literary Careers: The Author from Antiquity to the Renaissance'' (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2002). Edited with Patrick Cheney. * ''Writing for the Eyes in the Spanish Golden Age'' (Lewisburg: Bucknell University Press, 2004). * ''Ekphrasis in the Age of Cervantes'' (Lewisburg: Bucknell University Press, 2005). * ''Quixotic Frescoes: Cervantes and Italian Renaissance Art'' (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2006). * ''Hacia la tragedia: Lecturas para un nuevo milenio''. Biblioteca Áurea Hispánica 55 (Madrid/Frankfurt: Iberoamericana /Vervuert, 2008). Edited with Luciano Garcia Lorenzo and Enrique Garcia Santo-Tomas. * ''Ovid in the Age of Cervantes'' (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2010). * ''Don Quixote among the Saracens: A Clash of Civilizations and Literary Genres'' (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2011). * ''Calderón: del manuscrito a la escena''. Biblioteca Áurea Hispánica 75 (Madrid/Frankfurt: Iberoamericana/Vervuert, 2011). Edited with Luciano Garcia Lorenzo. * ''Objects of Culture in the Literature of Imperial Spain'' (Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2013). Edited with Mary E. Barnard. * ''Nuevas sonoras aves. Catorce estudios sobre Calderon de la Barca'' (Madrid: Iberoamericana, 2015). Edited with Antonio Sánchez Jiménez * ''El retorno de Astrea: Astrología, mito e imperio en Calderón''. Biblioteca Áurea Hispánica 108 (Madrid/Frankfurt: Iberoamericana/Vervuert, 2016). * ''La astrología en el teatro clásico europeo (Siglos XVI y XVII)'' (Madrid: Ediciones Antigona, 2017). * ''Autoridad y poder en el teatro del Siglo de Oro: estrategias y conflictos'' (New York: IDEA, 2017). Edited with Ignacio Arellano Ayuso. * ''Memorias de un honrado aguador: Ámbitos de estudio en torno a la difusión de Lazarillo de Tormes''. Prosa Barroca (Madrid: Sial, 2017). Edited with Julio Vélez Sainz.
==Bibliography: Fiction== * ''El abra del Yumurí'' (Madrid: Verbum, 2016) * ''Doce cuentos ejemplares y otros documentos cervantinos''. Instituto del Teatro de Madrid (Madrid: Ediciones Clásicas, 2016). Edited with Antonio Sánchez Jiménez * ''Sinfonía Salvaje'' (Madrid: Verbum, in press)
==See also== *[[List of University of Chicago people]]
==References== {{reflist}} *[http://rll.uchicago.edu/facultystaff/armas.shtml Staff page at University of Chicago] *[http://experts.uchicago.edu/experts.php?id=403 University of Chicago ''News''] *[http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/080612/dearmas.shtml U of Chicago ''Chronicle'']

{{Automatic_taxobox | name = ''Gadus'' | image = Atlantic cod.jpg | image_caption = ''[[Gadus morhua]]'', Atlantic cod | taxon = Gadus | authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]] {{cite web |author=WoRMS |year=2011 |title=''Gadus'' |editor=Nicolas Bailly |work=[[FishBase]] |publisher=[[World Register of Marine Species]] |url=http://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=125732 |accessdate=July 5, 2011}} | type_species = ''Gadus morhua'' | type_species_authority = Linnaeus 1758 | subdivision_ranks = Species | subdivision = *''[[Gadus macrocephalus]]'' *''[[Gadus morhua]]'' *''[[Gadus ogac]]'' *''[[Gadus chalcogrammus]]'' | synonyms = *''Cephus'' [[William John Swainson|Swainson]], 1838 *''Cerdo'' [[Johannes von Nepomuk Franz Xaver Gistel|Gistel]], 1848 *''Leptogadus'' [[Theodore Gill|Gill]], 1863 *''Morhua'' [[John Fleming (naturalist)|Fleming]], 1828 *''Morua'' [[Antoine Risso|Risso]], 1827 }} '''''Gadus''''' is a genus of [[demersal fish]] in the family [[Gadidae]], commonly known as [[cod]], although there are additional cod species in other [[genus|genera]]. The best known member of the genus is the [[Atlantic cod]]. Until recently, three species in the genus were recognized. Modern taxonomy also includes a fourth one, the [[Alaska pollock]] (''Gadus'' (=''Theragra'') ''chalcogrammus''), which is not separate from the [[Theragra finnmarchica|Norway pollock]].Eschmeyer W.F. (2012)[http://research.calacademy.org/redirect?url=http://researcharchive.calacademy.org/research/ichthyology/catalog/fishcatget.asp&tbl=species&spid=12393 ''chalcogrammus, Gadus''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220184433/http://research.calacademy.org/redirect?url=http%3A%2F%2Fresearcharchive.calacademy.org%2Fresearch%2Fichthyology%2Fcatalog%2Ffishcatget.asp&tbl=species&spid=12393 |date=2013-12-20 }} Catalog of Fishes. California Academy of Sciences.{{cite journal |vauthors=Coulson MW, Marshall HD, Pepin P, Carr SM |last-author-amp=yes |year=2006 |url=https://www.mun.ca/biology/dmarshall/Coulson_et_al_2006.pdf |title=Mitochondrial genomics of gadine fishes: implications for taxonomy and biogeographic origins from whole-genome data sets |journal=Genome |volume=49 |issue=9 |pages=1115–1130 |doi=10.1139/g06-083 |pmid=17110992 |access-date=2012-04-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220132047/https://www.mun.ca/biology/dmarshall/Coulson_et_al_2006.pdf |archive-date=2013-12-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Furthermore, [[Greenland cod]] (''G. ogac'') is no longer considered a distinct species but rather a subspecies of [[Pacific cod]] (''G. macrocephalus'').{{Cite journal | last1 = Carr | first1 = S. M. | last2 = Kivlichan | first2 = D. S. | last3 = Pepin | first3 = P. | last4 = Crutcher | first4 = D. C. | title = Molecular systematics of gadid fishes: Implications for the biogeographic origins of Pacific species | doi = 10.1139/z98-194 | journal = Canadian Journal of Zoology | volume = 77 | pages = 19–26 | year = 1999 | pmid = | pmc = }} {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- ! colspan="11"| True cod |- !
